p.seg: When the sea begins to move,
records various wonders,
If you pour a cup of water over the uneven floor of a room
then a small herb will serve as a boat on it,
Facing up to Heaven he breathed out wistfully
He felt lost, as if he had lost some counterpart.
Yan Cheng Ziyou stood in attendance before him
and said:
"Where have you gone off to?
Can one's physical shape really be made to resemble a shrivelled tree
and can one's mind be made to resemble dead ashes?
As you now are leaning on your armrest
you are not the one who leant on his armrest a moment ago.
Ziqi said:
"My dear Yan, you are surely doing very well to ask this question!
At this point I had lost sight of myself.
Have you any idea of this?
When you have learnt about the panpipes of men
that does not yet mean you have learnt about the pipes of Earth (herself);
When you have learnt about to the panpipes of Earth herself
that does not yet mean you have learnt about the panpipes of Heaven above.
Ziyou said:
"May I ask, then, how this is done?"
Ziqi said:
"Well then: the Great Clod throws up gas
and that gas is called "windy air".
This earth is basically inert,
but when it breaks into action then myriads of holes howl furiously.
Surely you have heard the wind sizzling away.
The treetops in the mountain forests,
the three hundred span wide hollows in the huge trees
they work like noses,
they work like mouths,
they work like ears,
they work like mugs,
they work like mugs,
they work like mortars,
they work like some kind of deep down puddles
they work like some kind of resonant sludge.
These are what gets whipped into action
what whizzes along,
what is shrieking away,
what catches breath,
what yells out
what moans
what guffaws,
what shrieks.
Those who take the lead sing forth
and those who follow suit sing along.
When there is a cool breeze all these produce a gentle harmony
and when there is a whirlwind there is an overwhelming harmony,
and when the fierce storms cease then all these orifices fall quite quiet.
Haven't you also been exposed to this seething and bleething sound?"
Ziyou said:
"So, the panpipes of Earth herself these are all those hollows
and the pipes of men, these are those bamboos, lined up.
But what about the pipes of Heaven?
Ziqi said:
"Well, their blowing varies in myriads of ways
and causes themselves to be themselves.
Given that they all choose what they are to be
who is it that blows the spirit into them?
Comprehensive understanding is idle,
petty knowledge is pedantic;
comprehensive speech is fiery,
petty speech is shrill.
While asleep one's soul reaches out,
and while one is awake one's body opens up.
What they touch, one engages with,
day in day out one struggles with one's mind.
confused as one is
contorted as one is,
inarticulate as one is.
petty fear is all fidgety,
great fear is all confused.
One bounds forth as from a crossbow
and that counts as sorting out right and wrong.
One is stubborn as if sworn to one's views as by an ancestral oath,
and this counts as guaranteeing success.
One withers away like autumn and winter
and that speaks of how day by day one fades.
One drowns in things, and what one has done
one cannot be allowed to return to.
One is locked down, as if sealed shut.
and that speaks of the idleness of one's old age,
and as one's mind closes in on death
nothing will allow it to return to the light of life.
Joy, anger, grief, and delight,
deliberation, wistfulness, change of mind, and stubborn insistence
decency, profligacy, open spontaneity, and a show of propriety
these are but music, they emerge from what is empty in itself,
these are mere steam bringing forth mushrooms
day and night they take their turns before us
and no one understands what they arise from.
Enough! Enough!
From morning to evening we are faced with these things
they are the sources from which we arise.
Without those things there is no Ego,
without an Ego there would be nothing that is chosen.
Surely, this is about it,
but one does not know for what purpose it is caused to be the way it is.
It is as if there is a genuine "master of the house",
the only thing is one does not find any trace of that master.
That he is capable of making oneself act (like a marionette player)
but I one does not see his shape.
He has a basic reality but no external form.
My two hundred joints
my nine apertures,
my six inner organs,
you are provided and you are in place.
But with which of you shall I identify?
"You should be satisfied with them all!" is that what you are saying?
But is there one among them to whom I am particularly close?
For if it is as you say, they are all in a way flunkeys, male and female?
And if they are flunkeys, male and female, they are are not in a position to keep order among each other.
Or are they then rulers and subjects for each other, taking turns?
Or is there a proper ruler who exists among them?
But no matter whether I seek and find the facts of this matter
this will neither strengthen nor weaken his genuine status.
Once one has received one's ready-made form
then one does not lose it until it until all is over.
One comes to blows with things, has one's brushes with things,
one's are as in a gallop, the whole lot of them,
and nothing is capable of calming one down so as to stop up.
Is that not sad?
All life one slaves away
and does not get to see any results achieved.
All worn out one slaves away, painfully,
never knowing what it is all about.
Can one fail to be upset by this?
Others point out that (at least) one is not dead:
but where does that help?
One's body degenerates
and so does one's mind.
Can one fail to consider this one big cause for grief.
While man is alive
he is inherently in this kind of muddle!
Or perhaps I alone am in a muddle
and among the others there are those who are not muddled?
Now if one follows one's made-up mind, as one's teacher.
then who in the world would be without a teacher? (No one would need a teacher!)
Why not make do with your own mind, [?????]
in order to have a teacher? (Why not make do with your mind?)
Even the stupid people have one of those.
Before fixing prejudice
to have notions of right and wrong
this is like (the logician's case of) "today setting out for Yue
and arriving some time ago."
This is to pass off what does not exist as existing:
But if you pass off what does not exist as existing
then even if a spiritual emperor Yu came along
he would still be incapable of understanding you.
How on earth would I manage?
Now speech is not just blown breath
when one speaks has something one is saying.
But what it is that one is saying is just not quite well-defined.
So then, in fact: is one really saying anything?
Or is one perhaps never actually saying anything?
When one imagines what one is saying is different from the fledgeling's chirping
is there really a difference?
Or is there perhaps no difference?
How does the Way become so obscured
that there comes to be the "genuine" versus the "fake"?
How do words become so obscured
that they come to have the "right" and the "wrong"?
Where can one go
without the Way existing there?
And how can speech exist
without it having a point?
The Way is obscured by petty prejudice
and words are obscured by rhetorical flourishes.
And as a result one has the "rights" and "wrongs" of the Confucians and the Mohists
so that these consider as "right" what those consider as "wrong"
and that these consider as wrong what those consider as right.
But if one wishes to take to be right what they each take to be wrong
and to take to be wrong what each take to be right,
then what one needs is clarity of thought.
Any object is a "that,
any object is a "this".
Starting from "that" one does not get to see things,
starting from one's own insight one "understands" them.
Thus is has to be said: the "that" (of the other) emerges from (one's own) "this".
but this "this" nonethless is also based on the "that".
And this is the thesis that "that" and "this" arise at the same moment.
This may be so
but as one is born one is at the same time dying,
as one is dying one is at the same time giving birth (to something new);
as one approves one is at the same time disapproving (of something else)
as one disapproves one is at the same time approving of something else
Based on "this", on that basis there is "not-this";
based on "not-this" on that basis there is "this".
It is by this reasoning that the sage does not follow the current ways
and instead throws light on things from the point of view (not of "this" or "that" "right" or "wrong" but) of Heaven.
But that, again, is also a basing oneself on what is "this"
And this "this" is nonetheless also a "that" (from someone else's point of view"),
the "that" in turn is nonetheless also a "this"
The "that" is at the same time a "this" and a "not-this".
And what I am now saying is at the same time "this" and "not-this".
So, in the end, is there something that is "that" or that is "this"?
Or, is there, in the end, nothing that is "that" or "this"?
That neither "that" nor "this" are opposed to anything
that is called the core point of the Way.
As soon as that core point reaches the centre of the ring
its responses thus are all-embracing.
The "this" is one - all-embracing;
that "not-this" is one - all-embracing.
That is why it says: what one needs is lucid insight.
Instead of using a mental picture to illustrate that this mental picture is not what depicts
one must use what is not (itself) a mental picture to show that that mental picture is not what it depicts.
Instead of using the mental picture of a horse to illustrate that this mental picture is not itself a horse
one must use what is not the mental picture of a horse to demonstrate that the mental picture of a horse is not itself a horse.
Heaven and Earth are (covered by) one mental picture;
the myriad kinds of things are covered by one one case of "horse".
A road becomes what it is by being walked on
things are what they are by being called what they are being called.
How does something become so-and-so?
(Just like that:) Its made so-and-so by becoming so-and-so!
How does something become not so-and-so?
(Just like that:) Its made not so-and-so by not becoming so-and-so!
Things definitely have a way of being so-and-so,
and things have a way of being acceptible;
No thing is other than as it is,
no thing is other than acceptable as it is.
They are made acceptable by being accepted
they are made unacceptable by being unaccepted.
And so no matter whethr you bring up the matter of a beam or a column
a leper or Xi Shi,
whatever crazy and strange things you bring up
their Way is the same throughout:
when they fall apart that is the completion of something else,
when they are completed, that is at the cost of the destruction of something else.
As a matter of principle, when things take their complete shape or are destroyed
they again reach out to form (another) unity.
Only a person of far reaching understanding understands this reaching out to form (another) unity.
Therefore such a man does not make things his concern
but takes his position in the overarching constancy of the Way.
The overarching constancy is what he uses;
and what he uses is overarching.
As for the overarching, he gets to it,
and when he happens to get to it he has reached the ultimate point.
This conditioned thisness/rightness he stops with.
What he stops with but of which he does not know it is true
this is called the Way.
Wearing out one's spirits doing one thing
and failing to understand that they are all the same
that is called "Three Every Morning".
What does Three Every Morning refer to?
It is this: When a certain monkey keeper was doling out acorns
he told his flock:
"In the morning you'll have three and in the evening four."
The whole lot of the monkeys were all furious.
So he said:
"Very well, then: Four every morning and three in the evening."
The whole lot of the monkeys were all satisfied.
In terminology and substance there was no deviation
but joy versus anger were displayed.
This was surely a conditioned assertion.
And with this in mind the Sage harmonises things out with assertions and denials,
and he rests in that Balance of Heaven.
THAT is what is called "having it both ways". (Not what the logicians call by that name.)
The men of old
had knowledge that reached a certain point.
Where did it get to?
There are those who take the stage when there had never begun to exist
to be the ultimate,
to exhaust (the knowable),
to be the point to which nothing can be added.
The next stage they took to be when there are things
but there were no fixed boundaries between them.
The next stage they took to be when there were fixed boundaries
but there had not begun to be evaluation by "right" and "wrong".
When "right" and "wrong" became prominent,
that was the reason why the Way was impaired,
and the reason why the Way was impaired
was at the same time the reason why emotional attachment (to one's own perspective on things) was formed.
But when all is said and done, do "formations" and "impairment" actually exist?
Or is there, when all is said and done, no such thing as "formation" and "impairment".
That the are "formation" and "impairment" exist
would explain the case of Mr Zhao strumming the lute;
that there is no such thing as "formation" and "impairment"
would then explain that Mr Zhao was not playing the lute.
Zhao Wen's strummingof the lute
Master Kuang's wielding his whip,
Huizi leaning against his wutong tree:
these three men's understanding went about as far as understanding can go.
They were all accomplished in their ways:
that is why their feats have been transmitted to our latter days.
Only on the point of their preferences
they came to be different from that other figure we were talking about;
and what they had their preference for
they wished to go on to clarify and glorify.
And those people clarifying and glorifying what in fact they did not understand.
As a result they ended up with (the logicians logical pedantries) on "hard" and "white".
and their offspring ended their days in written disquisitions,
but got nowhere to the end of their days.
Can that be called a success?
In that case even I would count as a success.
Or can that not be called a success?
In that case other creatures as well as I myself will never be a success.
And so, the glimmer of uncertainty and doubt
is what the sage envisages and copes with.
The subjectively "right" he has no use for,
his stance is in the invariable.
This is what is called using clear insight.
Now suppose we have a proposition here
and we have no idea whether it belongs to the category X
or whether it does not belong to the category X.
If "belonging to the category" and "not belonging to the category"
both constitute categorisation,
then in that sense (of both constituting categorisations) the "this" is no different at all from the "that"!
This may be so,
but please let me try to make such statements (as examples).
1. There is a beginning.
2. There is a stage where there has begun to be a beginning.
3. There is a stage where there has not begun to be a stage where there has begun to be a beginning.
4. There is existence.
5. There is absence.
6. There is a stage where there has not begun to be nothing.
7. There is a stage where there has not begun to be a stage where there has not begun to be nothing.
"All of a sudden there is nothing,
and I do not quite understand which of the "existence" and "non-existence" are (said to be) non-existent here.
Just now, as far as I am concerned, I have definitely have proposed something,
but I do not quite understand whether what I have proposed in point of fact does mean anything,
or whether in point of fact it does not mean anything.
1. "Nothing in the world is bigger than the tip of an autumn hair
and even Taishan counts as small."
2. "No one is more long-lived than a still-born child,
and Pengzu died young."
3. "Heaven and Earth have been born together with me
and the myriad kinds of creatures are one with me."
But since we are definitely already one
how can there come to be a statement?
And then, since I have definitely already called them one
how can it come to pass there was no statement?
The unity of all things together with the statement (that there is this unity) make two things.
And these two, together with their (supposed) unity count as three.
If we go on from this point
then even a clued-up numerate registrar cannot reach a conclusion. (Regress ad inifinitum.)
and how much less an untutored commoner.
And so if even from non-existence we happen to have a way of getting to three
how much better can we move from existence on to existence.
But one should never move on:
The Way has never begun to have fixed borders,
and speech has never begun to have fixed constancy.
When there is subjective truth there are (artificial) boundaries.
Allow me to speak of these (subjective) boundaries:
There is the (humble) "left" and there is the (noble)"right"
there are (personal) analyses and there are (political) debates,
there are (natural) differences and there are (logical) quibbles;
there is (personal) competition and there is (political) strife;
and for these eight one speaks of the Eight Virtues.
The things beyond the Six Realms
the sage leaves where they are and does not analyse;
the things within the Six Realms
the sage analyses but does not enter into political debate on.
The generations of the Annals and the aspirations of the Former Kings
the sage debates but does not quibble on.
Thus as for setting up distinctions
there remains what they do not distinguish;
as for quibbling
there remains what one does not quibble about.
You might say:
"So what?"
(The point is) the sage cognitively embraces things
while the hoi polloi quibble about them in order to show themselves off to each other.
Therefore it is said: as for logical quibbling
there are things it misse out on.
Now (for example) the Great Way one has no proper name for,
the Great Quibble does without words,
Great kind-heartedness is not kind-hearted,
Great Modesty is not modest,
Great Courage is not contentious.
When the Way appear it is not in accordance with the Way
when speech is quibbling it gets nowhere,
when kind-heartedness is rule-bound(?) it is not universal,
when modesty is immaculate it is suspicious,
if courage is contentious it is unsuccessful.
These five cases are, as they say "square but approximately moving towards the square."
And thus knowing how to stop where one does not know,
that is the ultimate.
But who understands the wordless quibbles,
the Way that does not play the "Way".
If there is someone who is capable of understanding this
then this a Treasurehouse from Heaven.
It pours into him (with wisdom) but he does not get full,
one tastes from him but will not take away from him,
and the point is he does not know wherefrom all this comes to him.
This is called the Guardian of the Light.
It is against this background we have the story of Yao asking Shun:
"I want to launch a formal attack against Zong m Kuai, and Xuao,
but facing south to ruler the world I don't feel well at ease.
What is the reason behind this?
Shun replied:
"Well, these three
And now you don't feel at ease. Why that should be?
In olden times ten suns rose together
are survivers in the sticks
and all kinds of creatures were bathing in blazing sunlight,

how much more should this be the case with virtue which is of a higher order than the sun! （You feel uneasy because you are wasting your time: they will emerge from the sticks of their own accord! 不足掛齒！)
Toothless asked Weakling Wang:
"Do you know what all creatures in common deem right?
He said: "How could I ever know that?"
But do you know what it is that you do not know?
He said:
"How could I ever know that?"
"Does that mean that creatures have no certain knowledge (since they cannot know what is universally agreed on)?"
He said:
"How could I ever know that?"
Well then:
let me try to put this into words:
(The question is:) How do we know that what we call "knowing" is not a case of "not knowing"?
And how do we know that what we call "not knowing" is not a case of "knowing"?
Moreover, let be keep asking you some questions:
"If the common people sleep on soggy wet mattresses
then their waists will ache, and they will be numb on one side.
But is that true of the eel?!
And if that eel has to survive in a tree then it will be scared out of its mind.
But there again, is that true of an NN monkey?
Which of these kinds of creatures "know" what is the "right" abode?
The common people eat the meat of grass-fed and grain-fed animals
the milu deer eat jian-grass
the centipede prefers the eyes of certain small snakes
The sparrowhawd as well as the raven have a taste for mice:
which of these four kinds of creatures "knows" the "right taste"?
Monkeys of the qiu, bian and ju kind treat each other as sexual objects,
deer of the mi and the lu kind copulate,
qiu fish dally with other fish.
Mao Qiang and Li Ji were held to be beautiful
but any fish would dive deep at the sight,
and any bird would fly high at the sight.
and the milu deer would rush off.
Of these four kinds of creatures which one understands true sexiness?
From my (biased) perspective
the principles of morality like benevolence and rectitude
the path of "right and wrong",
these are all in a complete mess.
How should one be capable of understanding these logical quibbles?
Toothless said:
"If you don't understand profit and harm
then presumably the perfect man does not understand profit and harm?"
Weakling Wang said:
The person of ultimate attainment has something spiritual about him:
The great marshes may burn, but this is incapable of making him hot,
The Yellow River and the River Han may freeze, but this is incapable of making him cold,
the sudden thunder may smash the mountains,
the storms may shake the sea
but these are incapable of making him panic.
Someone of this sort
rides along on the clouds and even on the air
astride on sun and moon
he roams beyond the Four Seas.
Death or life make no difference to himself,
not to speak of the principles of profit and harm."
Magpie Ju was asking questions of Tall Wutong:
"I have heard from our master
'The sage does not serve his own motives
he does not go for (undue) profit,
he does not avoid (necessary) harm,
he does not enjoy pursuit,
he does conform to any Way
by not stating things he makes a (higher) statement,
by stating things, he makes no (ordinary) statement.
and so he roams beyond the mere dust and dirt of this world.
Our master regarded these as wildly extravagant statements,
but I regard this as the very practice of the Superb Way
What are your impressions on this?"
Tall Wutong said:
"In the ears of a Yellow Emperor this would cause confusion
so how would our friend Confie be qualified to understand it?
Moreover you yourself are greatly overhasty in your assessment:
You notice an egg, and expect the morning call of the cock,
you see a crossbow and expect a ready-roasted bird.
Let me try to provide for you a crazy account of this,
and you must listen to these in the same crazy spirit.
So how does this work?
One sides with the sun and the moon,
one holds the universe of space and time under one's armpit.
One deals with that amalgamation of things
and leaves thema lone in their messy chaos:
as a slave he honours that mess.
Ordinary people are busibodies
the sage is dull and blunt:
He partakes in the evolution of all the myriads of bygone years but a single person achieves an inner purity.
All things, without exception, he takes for what they are
and in this way makes them his accumulated treasure.
'How am I to be sure that being satisfied with life is not a case of being misguided?
how am I to be sure that hating death is not a case of a little child having lost its home
and having no idea about getting back.'" LIEZI parallel must be quoted.
Li Zhiji was a daughter of a border official in Ai.
When the state of Jin first got hold of her
her tears streamed over her collars
and only when it came to getting to the King's place
to share the bamboo bed with him
to eat the means of grass- and grain-eating animals,
after all that did she regret her tears.
How would I ever be certain that those who have died are not regretting that they had been so attached to life.
After dreaming that one was feasting on wine
in the morning one wakes up all wailing and weeping;
after dreaming that one is wailing and weeping
in the morning one wakes up to go on a happy hunt.
While dreaming
one is not aware that one is dreaming
and in one's dream one will go on to divine the meaning of the dream.
Sure enough: only after one has woken up does one come to understand it was a dream,
but in addition it is only after the great awakening that one comes to understand that it is all just one big dream.
But the stupid consider themselves to have woken up:
that unbeknownst to others they understand their situation.
You're a ruler, eh?
A shepherd, eh?
Thick is what you are!
Our Confi and you, you are figments of dreaming.
And when I call you a figment of dreaming
that in itself is a figment of dreaming.
Words of this order (identifying oneself as this or that)
are properly called a lamentable fraud.
After myriads of generations one will all at once have a great sage,
and his understanding of the unraveling of all this.
And this meeting will be a matter of no more than one daytime.
Let us assume that I have a quibble with you.
If you win against me
and I am not up to you,
will you then, in fact, be right,
and will I then be wrong?
If I beat you
and you are are not up to me
am I then in fact, right,
and are you then, in fact, wrong?
Is someone right here,
and someone else here wrong?
Or are both right,
or again are both wrong?
If I and you are incapable of being sure of this
then others will certainly participate in this profound dark muddle.
Whom shall we employ to sort out the matter objectively?
Shall we employ someone who agrees with you to sort out the matter objectively.
But since he agrees with you (to start with)
how is he capable to sort out the matter objectively?
Shall we employ someone who agrees with me to sort out the matter objectively
how can he sort out the matter objectively?
Shall we employ someone who differs on this with both of us to sort out the matter objectively?
Since he agrees with me (to start with)
Since he differs on this with both of us
how can he sort ou the matter objecitvely.
Shall we employ someone who agrees on this with both of us?
Since he agrees on this with both of us,
how can he sort out the matter objectively.
It follows that I, you and that third person (agreeing with both of us) have this in common that they cannot be sure of this matter.
So is this a case for depending on yet another person?
As for the mutual dependence (relativity) of these changing pronouncements (on "right" and "wrong"
if they are not to be relative (any more)
one must harmonise them with the Equaliser of Heaven
adapt to them in accordance with their uncontrolled evolution:
that is how one can live out the years of one's lifespan.
What is meant by "harmonising things with the Equaliser of Heaven?
The method is this:
"Regard what is "not right" as right,
regard as "true" what is not true.
For if what is "right" were ultimately right
then regarding the difference between "right" and "wrong"
would surely be beyond dispute;
if things were ultimately "true",
then the difference between truth and untruth
would surely be beyond dispute.
One must disregard one's lifetime, disregard what is "just and proper",
and sally forth into the boundless."
Penumbra asked Shadow:
"One moment you are walking,
and the next moment you are standing still;
one moment you are sitting down
and the next moment you rise up.
Why are you so inconstant?"
The Shadow said:
"Could it be that I depend on something to be as I am, (you Stupid!)?
And does not what I rely on has in turn something it depend on?
Am I depending on snake's scales, or on cicada wings?
How would I be aware of why I am as I am?
How would I be aware of why I am not as I am not?
Some time ago Zhuang Zhou dreamt he became a butterfly,
a butterfly fluttering along,
pleased with my butterfly self as having reached my ambition.
I knew nothing of any "Zhou".
All of a sudden I woke up,
and then as messily as ever I was old Zhou!
But I had no idea whether Zhou had been dreaming he was a butterly,
or whether a butterfly has been dreaming it was Zhou.
Between Zhou and a butterfly
there definitely is a difference.
But this is called the Transmogrification (as opposed to the ordinary transformation and evolution) of Things.
One's life has its bounds
but the realm of what one ought to know has no bounds:
with the bounded to pursue what has no bounds is disastrous.
THE IMPORTANT POINT IN NOURISHING LIFE
With such knowledge to consider oneself to know things, that is simply disastrous.
When doing good one must avoid getting anywhere close to fame,
when doing evil one must avoid getting anywhere close to punishment.
One must be guided by the spine (spinal reaction... 李贄), take that to be the guideline:
then you can preserve your person whole
you can live out your life,
you can take care of your parents
and live out your full lifespan.
Cook Ding was dissecting an ox for Prince Wenhui:
wherever his hand pushed,
wherever his should leant,
wherever his foot trod,
wherever his knee shoved,
he wielded his knive so smoothly

Confucius: "You are not paying enough attention.

Duke Ai of Lu asked Confucius:
"In Wey there was a very ugly man by the name of Ai Taituo.
The men who staying with him
think of no one else and are incapable of bringing themselves to leave him,
the ladies who laid eyes on him asked their parents:
'Rather than being another's wife I'd want to be that man's concubine"

There was never anyone who heard Taituo calling the tune,
he always fell in with others others that was all.
He did not have any position of a ruler over others
so he might have been able to aid those in danger of death;
he had no accumulated assents
Moreover, while with his ugliness he scared the wits out of everyone,
he fell in with things and did not try to call the tune (in the spirit of Montaigne):
he had not knowledge of anything beyond the world around him.
And yet everyone, males and females got together to listen to him.
There had to be something that made him different from (all the) others.
I summoned him to see what kind of a man he was.

and no more than a year went by

I was deeply affected by his departure, as if someone (close) had died:

they loved that which governed that physical shape.

and Yao and Shun thereupon set to work so hard there was no hair left on their thighs,

he threw out the San Miao to settle in Sanwei;

When the Yellow Emperor had been Son of Heaven for nineteen years
his orders were carried out throughout the world.
When he heard about Guang Chengzi up on his Mount Empty-All-The-Same
he went along and paid him his respects to him:
and said:
"I understand that you have attained to the Ultimate Way
and I would like to ask you about the subtle essence of the Ultimate Way.
You see, I would like to grasp the essence of Heaven and Earth
so as to support the growth of the five kinds of grain and to take good care of the common people;
in addition to that I would like to get an administrative hold on Yin and Yang
so as to bring all living creatures to fruition:
how am I to go about this?"
Guang Chengzi said:
"What you would like to ask about
are the substantial features of all beings;
and what you would like to get administrative control of
is the decay of all things.
But since you are ruling the world
it is raining before the cloudy air has even massed together,
the plants and trees shed their leaves before they have even gone brown,
the bright heat of sun and moon have increased so much that they lead to droughts.
Now you, with your mindset of a wise-cracker, bombastic as hell,
how could you ever be qualified to talk about the Ultimate Way?"
The Yellow Emperor withdrew,
he simply ditched his empire
built himself a datcha,
he used white rushes as his mat
and for three months he lived a life of leisure,
then he went over again for a meeting with the man.
Guang Chengzi - facing south - was taking a nap.
The Yellow Emperor, as the situation required, found himself facing north,
moving on his knees he moved forward,
twice he bowed, knocking the ground with his forehead in submission he asked:
"I understand you have attained to the Ultimate Way
may I ask, then, how can one take lasting good care of one's person?
Guang Chengzi got up with a sudden start,
and he said:
"Excellent question!
Come here!
I shall talk to you about the Ultimate Way.
The essence of the Ultimate Way is (as Laozi 21 has it) far-reaching and obscurely so
the apogee of the Ultimate Way is inarticulate and dumb.
It consists in focussing on nothing, listening to nothing
enveloping one's spirit with serenity:
your body will then take its proper form all of itself.
You must absolutely be serene; one must absolutely be pure,
you must never wear out your body
you must never rattle your subtle spirits,
then you will be able to have a long life.
When your eyes see nothing
when your ears hear nothing,
when your mind knows nothing,
then your spirits will get to guard your body,
and that is when your body will live long.
Pay diligent attention to what is within you
block off what is without you:
multifarious knowledge brings defeat.
I will cause you to realise yourself up above the the Great Enlightenment
so you will reach that origin of the Ultimate Yang;
I will cause you to enter into the Gate of the Far-Reaching-Inarticulate
so you will reach the origin of the Ultimate Yin.
Heaven and earth have their cosmic bureaucrats in charge
Yin and Yang have their troves,
but as for you, you had better diligently guard your person
and all the things about you will thrive all of themselves.
I for my part guard the unity within me so as to dwell in its harmony.
And so I have cultivated my person for all of twelve thousand years,
and (as you see) my body has never declined."
The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, knocked the floor with his forehead and said:
"Guang Chengzi, you are practically bloody Heaven!"
Guang Chengzi said:
"Come here!
I shall talk to you about this.
Those things of this world are immeasurable
but (we) men all imagine there is an end to them;
these things of the world are in no way fathomable,
but (we) men all imagine they have their extreme point.
Whosoever attains to my Way will become a god above and a king here below;
whosoever fails of my Way
will see the light up in the sky
but here below he will count as so much dust of this world.
Now all those thriving beings in this world are born from the dust of the earth and return to the dust of the earth.
So I'm going to leave you alone
and entering through the Gate of Infinitude
I shall roam in the Field of Boundlessness.
I shall join my light with sun and moon,
I shall share my consistencey with that of Heaven and Earth
What I am facing I blend with,
what is far from me I am blind to.
Men must all die, the whole lot of them,
but I alone will persist!"

Roaming in this way in the busy hassle of this world [See Lin Xiyi] so as to survey the Undeluded Truth (about it all),

discard your body and limbs

The hoi polloi of this world
all find it pleasant when others concur with them
and they hate it others diverge from them.
When they desire the things that concur with them
and do not desire the things that diverge with them,
this is because they make it their overall ambition to rise above the numerous crowd.
But the fact is that those who make it their overall ambition to rise above the numerous crowd
when have they ever risen above the numerous crowd.
One must adapt to the preferences of the numerous crowd, for one's peace of mind
because whatever one has learnt it is not as numerous as the numerous competences of the numerous crowd.
You are the sort of fellow who wishes he could govern a state that is not his own.
This is to go after the benefits of the Three Royal Systems (the three dynasties)
and never to notice the serious problems involved in that project.
This is to try one's luck with a state that is not one's own:
how long can you be so lucky to last and not lose control of that state which is not your own?!
Now those who successfully ensure the continued existence of someone else's state are not as many as one in a myriad.
The chances that one loses control of someone else's state is less than one in ten thousand.
Sad it is, is it not,
that those who are in charge of territories do not have a clue about all this.
The fact is that being in charge of a territory
is to be in charge of a very big thing;
And when one is in charge of a big thing
one cannot oneself be a mere thing.
One is a thing but not to act as a mere thing
and as a result one is capable to treating other things as mere things.
If you are clear about the fact that he who treats things as mere things is not himself a mere thing
how would you only be able to govern the peoples of the world, and no more?
You will leave and enter the realm of this world (at your will)
and you will roam throughout the Nine Regions,
on your initiative you will come, on your own initiative you will go,
and as such one is called an Independent Being.
As for a person who is an Independent Being
he is said to have reached the Ultimate Nobility.
The teaching of the Great Man
is like the response of the shadow to a body
the response of an echo to a sound:
when there is a question he responds to that question
and he says all that is on his mind
becomes a companion to anyone in the world (asking questions of him).
As he is dwelling by himself he gives no echo (his only action is REaction, response),
his action follows not recipe of action.
He lifts the hubbub of your goings and comings
so as to make you roam in the Boundless
to make you go in and out of the Neighbourless,
like the sun to not ever have a (real) beginning
to sing the praise of ratiocinations, shapes, and bodies,
to integrate into the Great Congruence,
to be greatly congruent and to have no Self.
When he has no self
how can there ever get to exist existents (for a non-existent Self)?
Those who faces existents
are the 'gentlemen' of former
those who face the nothingness of everything
are the Friends of Heaven and Earth.
That which is not worth our attention but must be worked on is this:
things;
those who are base but must inevitably be adapted to
are the common people;
that which is inconsequential but must inevitably be addressed
are one's undertakings;
that which is hopelessly crude but must inevitably be proclaimed
are the laws;
that which is remote but must inevitably engaged in
is duty;
that which is of the intimate kind but must inevitably be generalised
is benevolence;
that which naturally constrains but must inevitably be elaborated
is ritual propriety;
that which is at the central core but must inevitably be raised to a high position
is Virtue;
that which is uniquely itself but must inevitably be varied in application
is the Way;
that which is supernatural and spiritual but must inevitably be worked on
is High Heaven.
Hence it is that the Sage has Heaven in full view
but he does not try to help Heaven
he works on realising Virtue
but he does not pile up virtuous deeds;
he starts from the Way
but he does not plan for the Way;
he rallies to benevolence
but he does not rely on it (or build on it, as a reified standard);
he leans towards duty
but does not amass dutiful acts;
he responds to the demands of ritual propriety
but he observes no taboos;
he engages with tasks
but he does not verbalise them;
he takes laws to be (ultimately) all the same,
but he does not create (legal) havoc;
he relies the common people
but he does not despise them;
he accommodates to things
but he does not completely dismiss them.
The things of this world are never worth aiming for
but must not fail to deal with them.
If one is not clear on matters of Heaven
or if one is not pure in matters of Virtue,
of if one does not have a comprehensive vision of the Way
then one has no basis on which to find anything acceptable.
Someone who is not clear about the way
is in a sorry state, is he not?
But what do we call the Way?
It is to have the Way of Heaven
and to have the Way of man.
If it is detachment that one holds in highest honour
that is the Way of Heaven;
if one does act (insofar as one has no alternative) and gets tied up with things
that is the Way of man.
The most important thing is the Way of Heaven
and the secondary Way is the Way of man.
The Way of Heaven and the Way of man are far distant from each other,
and this distinction must be clearly kept in mind.
Heaven and Earth may be large
but its transformations are even;
the things in this world may be many
but the régime that dominates them is one;
manpower may be abundant in this world
but they are dominated by one single ruler.
Rulerhood has its source in Virtue
and is brought to fruition in Heaven.
Therefore it is said:
"The inscrutable ancient rulership over the world consisted in detached non-interference,
it was a matter of Virtue conveyed by Heaven.
They looked upon words from the (broad) angle of the Way
and the rulership over the world was (naturally) correct;
they looked upon social divisions from the (broad) angle of the Way
and the duties of rulers and subjects became (naturally) clear;
they looked upon abilities (of officials)
and all the offices in the world were (naturally) well-governed;
they looked upon whatever it was from the (broad) angle of the Way
and the response to all things was consummate.
Thus having a broad angle on Heaven and Earth
is a matter of Virtue,
dealing in practice with all the things in this world
is a matter of the Way.
For superiors to govern others
is a task (to undertake);
for one's capacities to have something to be professional with
is a matter of systematic technique.
Systematic technique are tied to tasks,
tasks are tied to duties,
duties are tied to Virtues,
Virtue is tied to the Way,
and the Way is (ultimately) tied to Heaven.
Thus it is said:
In the ancients' care for the world
there was nothing these ancients wanting to achieve, but everyone (naturally) had enough;
they cultivated detached non-interference but all the world's creatures (naturally) went through their evolutions;
these ancient rulers were profoundly calm
and all the families under their rule found their settled place.
There is an account that says:
"When one has a broad understanding of the One Crucial Thing,
then all tasks will be settled:
the state of 'mindless' Indifference is achieved
and the ghosts and spirits give up and surrender.
Our Master says:
"The Great Way holds up Heaven and covers Earth and it is what transforms and engenders all the world's things:
it is overwhelming in its immensity.
The gentleman cannot fail to crack his mind in the effort to understand it.
To be disengaged in what one does is called the mode of Heaven,
to be disengaged in the way one talks about things is called Virtue,
to love others and work for the benefit of other creatures is called benevolence,
to envision on a par what is different is called greatness,
in one's actions not be limited by what deviates form the customary is called greatness of sould (envergure);
to comport within oneself myriads of potentialities is called (spiritual) affluence;
Holding onto Virtue as before is the general pattern (of all things);
for this Virtue to be realised, that is to be Firmly Established;
following hte Way is called Being Fully Prepared,
not to impair one's aspirations for the sake of (mere) things is called Consummation.
When the true gentleman has a clear view on these ten concepts,
then he encompasses the overarching nature of his work on the mind,
and he cascades along as he handles the natural flow of all things.
In so doing
he stores gold in a mountain,
stores pears in an abyss,
thinks nothing of possessions
never goes near the noble or the rich,
takes no special pleasure in long life,
does not mourn for early death,
does not glory in success,
does not feel bad about being a failure:
his spiritual dimension is not limited to what is beneficial during one particular generation
so that he comes to consider it as his own selfish destined part;
he does not regard the rulership over the world
to be an preeminent position for himself.
His preeminence
則明 consists in the recognition that all things of the world constitute one storehous,
that death and life constitute one and the same physical constellation.
The Master said:
Now when it comes to the Way
deep is its abode,
limpid its sublime purity.
When metal bells and music stones fail to attain to it they have not what it takes to 'sing (properly, in tune)'.
[Thus there is (potential) sound in metal and in stone (instruments),
but unless they are beaten they do not sing. COMMENTARY INTRUSION]
Who can adequately describe all the things of this world?
Now a person with the Virtue of a king
goes along as ever with the flow of things, and he is ashamed to engage with the concrete business of life:
he takes his solid stand in the Basic Source
and his understanding engages with the spirits.
Therefore his Virtue reaches far and wide.
When his mind does sally forth there has been something that has provoked him to it (always responding like a bell, never taking any initiative).
Thus it is that without the Way no physical shape arises,
and when a physical shape arises, without Virtue (i.e. the Power of the Way) it will never be clearly manifested.
Preserving one's physical shape and living out one's life,
firmly establishing Virtue and having a clear vision of the Way
is that in itself not Regal Natural Power?
Leave it Be
Out of the blue!
All of a sudden he turns up,
immediately he takes action
and all things follow him naturally.
This is called a a man of Regal Natural Power.
He looks into what is utterly obscure,
he listens into what makes no sound (i.e. the Way).
In that utter obscurity (of the Way)
he is the only one who sees the light;
in that complete soundlessness (of the Way)
he is the only one has an ear for the hidden harmony.
In the depths beyond depths he is capable of of spotting the crucial thing,
in the supernatural beyond the supernatural he is capable to spot the subtle essence:
that is why he naturally relates to all things of the world,
being the ultimate Nothing he ministers to their demands,
racing along with the passing moments he finds in them temporary lodging
for the large and the small, for the long and the short, for what is close and what is far away
for each of these he has what it takes."

he is in a position to serve as the 'father' of the ordinary people,

when the Way does not prevail in the world

he will ride those white misty clouds

Bocheng Zigao
retired from his position as a feudal lord and turned to farming.

you were enfeoffed as a feudal lord.

In the Primeval Beginning there was the Void:
it had no existence, it had no name.
And when the One arose,
there was indeed the One, but it did not yet have any physical shape.
What thing get so that they will arise
is called the inherent Power. FANTASTIC DEFINITION TO KEEP IN MIND!!!
When things were not yet formed they already had their fated features:
their being about to be realised, without disruption,
that is called their destiny.
As that which is static moves, it brings forth things:
when things are formed they bring forth well-defined features (li)
and this is called their physical shape.
When physical shape and body maintain within themselves a '(unifying) spirit',
and they each display their regular features
then that (i.e. these regular features) are called the basic nature (of things).

"(Well,) Shun just passed on the rulership to Shun,
Shun passed on the rulership to Yu,
Yu used force,
Tang used military force,
King Wen complied with tyrant Zhou
and did not dare to oppose him,
King Wu opposed Zhou
and was not willing to comply with him
that is why I maintained their styles were different."
Lao Dan said:
"Well, young man, come closer still!
Let me tell you about the Three Kings and the Five Emperors and their government of the world:
When the Yellow Emperor governed the world
he got the people to be well-aligned in their minds:
when the people had parents that died, but he did not wail (as ritual prescribes)
then the people did not criticise him for that.
When Yao governed the world
he got the people to be caring in their minds:
when the people, for the sake of their parents, treated more distant relatives with more distant respect
then the people would not criticise them for that.
When Shun governed the world
he got the people to fend for themselves:
the mothers among the pople did give birth after (the standard) ten months,
but the children began to be able to talk by the the time they were five months old,
and before they got to the stage where they could smile they started to know who was who,
and so at this point there began to be premature death of men.
When Yu governed the world
he got the people to inconstant in their minds,
and so people had their own minds and weapons got used quite naturally:
after all, killing a thief is not killing,
people will work for their own race, and thus it is throughout the world, that is all (so it is not Yu's fault alone, it is a common feature everywhere)
Under these circumstances all the world got upset
the Confucians and the Mohists all made their appearance,
and through their artifice there came to be ethical standards,
and today even regarding wives and daughters - why go on about that?
Let me tell you this:
When the Three Sovereigns and the Five Emperors were governing the world
in name they were governing indeed,
but in fact there is no greater misrule than theirs.
The craftiness of the Three Sovereigns
offended against the brightness of sun and moon above
and below their 'government' ran counter to the very essence of mountains and streams,
and in addition it destroyed the bounty of the Four Seasons.
Their artificial craftiness was more devastating than the tail of a scorpion:
even of the least of the animals
and yet those sovereigns fancied themselves as sages:
was it not something to be thoroughly ashamed of
their shamelessness"
Zigong was left standing there, squirming, ill at ease.
Confucius said to Lao Dan:
"I've been working on the Six Classics, the Odes, the Documents, the Rituals, Music,
the Changes, and the Annals.
I think myself this has taken along time,
and I've got familiar with the contents of these.
In this way I sought out any number of rulers,
I have assessed the Way(s??) of the Former Kings,
and I have elucidated the traces left by the Duke of Zhou and the Duke of Shao (i.e. Shi 奭),
but I was not picked out for employment by a single ruler.
Isn't it amazing how hard it is to persuade others,
how hard it is to elucidate the Way!"
Laozi said:
Good for you that you did not chance upon any ruler presiding over a well-governed generation!
Those Six Classics of yours
are the well-trodden traces of the Former Kings,
they are not the crucial reason why they left these traces.
What you are now poposing
are also mere traces.
And those traces
are what shoes leave behind,
but how could traces ever be shoes?
When the white kingfishers look at each other, without moving their eyeballs
and when on heat they are impregnated;
With the insects
the male chirps up above
the female chirps down below,
and they are impregnated.
The mythical lei-weasel treats itself as both female and male,
and when on heat gets impregnated that way.
One's inborn nature cannot be exchanged for another,
one's destiny cannot be transmuted,
time cannot be stopped,
the Way cannot be blocked.
If one really has got hold of the Way
there are no grounds for anything to be unacceptable,
if one has lost one's grip on this Way
there are no grounds for anything to be acceptable."
Confucius did not leave his hime for three months after this
and then he paid another visit to Lao Dan:
"Now I've got the knack:
the raven and the magpie lay egs,
the fish feed their young (=哺）with spittle,
the slimwaist insects have their own way of getting impregnated.
When a younger brother arrives
the elder brother keeps crying.
It is a long time since I have ceased to identify with the transformation of things.
And when one does not identify with the transformation of things
how can one transform and educate others?"
Laozi said:
"OK,
my friend, now you've got the point!"
Tailoring one's thought, elevating one's conduct,
distancing oneself from the world, deviating from the vulgar,
cultivating lofty discourse, and spiteful polemics:
this is just to engage>indulge in haughtiness.
It is what the gentleman in the remote mountains and valleys is fond of,
the critic of his own time
the dissicated recluse rushing towards the abyss (to take his life).
Talking about benevolence, duty, loyal devotion and good faith
politeness, moderation, deference,
these are just matters of cultivation;
and this is to the taste of the gentleman who has made his peace witht he world,
the man who trains and instruct others,
and the itinerant intellectual.
Talking about great undertakings,
establishing a great name for oneself,
cultivating polite relations between ruler and minister,
straightening out (more generally) the relations between superiors and their inferiors,
this is just to engage in politics;
and this is to the taste of the gentlemen at court,
the men associated with honoured rulers or from powerful states,
the achievers and the usurpers.
Going to live in the marshes,
dwelling out in the open,
angling fish and having a leisurely time
that is just non-interference in the world;
and this is to the taste of the migrant gentlemen of the rivers and seas,
the people who escape from the mundane world
the men of idle indolence.
exhaling and inhaling,
belching out the old, taking in the new,
breathing lie the bear, stretching like the bird
that is just working towards a long life;
this is to the taste of the adherents of qigong,
the men who build up their bodies,
emulators of the longlived heroes of the order of Pengzu.
{{{NB: Wang Xianqian has "子常語諸梁也"}}}
Without tailouring one's thought to reach high,
without benevolence and duty to cultivate one's person,
without achievements or reputation to practise good government,
without rivers and seas to be at ease,
without qigong to live long;
to forget about everything
and yet to have everything;
peaceful and boundless,
so that all the splendour of the world naturally attaches to one,
this is the Way of Heaven and Earth,
it is the inherent Power of the sage.
Therefore it is said:
serenity, calm, openness, indifference,
these constitute the peace of Heaven and Earth,
they are the substance of the inherent Power of the Way.
Therefore it is said:
the sage is at rest with things,
if one is at rest he is at peace and at ease,
if one is at peace and at ease he is detached;
if one is at peace, at ease and detached
no worries of any kind can enter one,
deviant vital forces are incapable of invading one's person:
and so one's inherent Power is unimpaired, one's spirit undiminished.
Therefore it is said:
The life of the sage is the working of Heaven
his dying is the transmogrification of things:
when at rest the sage partakes of the inherent Power of Yin
when in action he partakes of the billowing of Yang.
The sage is not the harbinger of good luck,
nor is he the source of bad luck:
only when moved does he respond,
only when pressed does he take action,
only when forced by circumstance rise to take an initiative.
He dismisses cleverness and reasoning
and follows the patterns from Heaven.
And so he suffers no disasters from Heaven,
no entanglements with things,
no criticisms from others,
no blame from the ghosts.
His life is like a floating through existence,
his dying is like a resting from existence.
He does not engage in reflection about the present
and makes no plans for the future;
bright as he is he does not shine,
faithful as he is he is not predictable.
When asleep he does not dream,
when awake he does not worry;
his spirit is pure,
his soul unfatigued.
He is open, unpreoccupied, and serene
and therein lies his congruence with the inherent Power from Heaven.
Therefore it is said:
"Sadness and delight
are deviance from one's natural potential,
joy and anger
are transgressions against one's natural potential,
fondness and hatred
are failures to live up to one's natural potential.
Thus, for the mind to be free from worries and joys
that is the consummation of one's natural potential;
to be one, and unchanging,
that is the the consummation of stillness;
not to be at odds with anything
that is the consummation of empty openness;
not to interact with external things
that is the consummation of limpid tranquility;
not to revolt against anything
that is the consummation of unadulterated purity.
Therefore it is said:
When the body is worn-out and finds no rest one gets decrepit,
when the subtle spirit ceaselessly used, one one will be worn-out
and once one is word-out one is spent.
It is in the nature of water
that if unmixed with other things, it is clear and pure,
and if not moved by something else it is plain;
when blocked up and prevented from flowing along
it also is incapable of being clear and pure:
water is a symbol for natural potential from Heaven.
Therefore it says:
To remain completely pure and undiluted,
to remain still and not change,
to remain tranquil and be indifferent,
when making a move to do so by the workings of Heaven,
this is the Way of nourishing the spirit.
Now someone who owns a sword from Gan or Yue
will put in a box and keep it well,
and he won't dare to use it:
this is because such a sword is precious in the extreme.
To let one's spirits reach out in all diretions and let them flow freely,
arriving at all of the world's extremes,
touching Heaven above,
wriggling on Earth below
transmogrifying all things in the world,
without being made a symbol of anything in particular,
such a person is said to be Imperial God-like.
The Way of pure pristineness
is to guard carefully only the spirit,
to guard it carefully and never to let go of it,
to become One with that spirit.
The subtle keenness of this One
enters into a communion with the Rules of Heaven.
There is a popular saying:
"The hoi polloi will value profit,
the immaculate gentlemen will value reputation,
the worthy gentlemen will value highly aspirations,
and the sage values most highly the subtle essences of the spirit.
So as for pristineness
this refers to the absence of any admixture in a thing;
as for purity,
it refers to keeping the spirit unimpaired:
and one capable of spiritually embodying purity and pristineness
is called a real Mensch.
ENHANCING INBORN NATURE
Enhancing inborn nature to through vulgar current study
in order thus to try to get back to the original state
confusing one's desires through current vulgar reflection
in order thus to reach insight,
those who follow these lines are called obtuse halfwits.
Those who, in ancient times, were working on the Way
nurtured wisdom through quietude,
the lived their lives and thought nothing of wisdom,
and that is called to nurture quietude through wisdom.
When wisdom and quietude nurture each other
and the harmonious guiding patterns emerge from inborn nature.
One's natural potential is a matter of harmony,
and the Way is a matter of guiding principles.
When one's natural potential encompasses everything,
this is benevolence;
when one's way is in nowhere not guided by natural principles
this is dutifulness;
when duties are clear and creatures of this world feel close to each other
this is fealty;
when one is tuned in to pure truth and reverts the basic reality,
this is music;
when one conducts faithfully one face and body, and one keeps in accordance with civilised decorousness,
this is ritual propriety.
But when ritual propriety and music are everpresent everywhere
then the world will be in chaos.
When these things are practised punctiliously they obfuscate their own inherent potential,
and this potential will then not sally forth:
when one insists on making this potential sally forth then the things will lose their basic nature.
The ancients
lived in a world of total turmoil
along with all their contemporaries they were unperturbed by all that.
At that time
Yin and Yang were at harmonious peace
the ghosts and spirits did not upset them,
the Four Seasons kept their rhythms,
all kinds of things of the world went unharmed,
all living creatures did not die early deaths,
men may have had some knowledge
but they had nothing to use it on:
this was called the Ultimate One.
At this time
no one was doing anything about it but all was in permanent natural shape.
But when it came to the point when this natural potential declined,
as when Suiren and Fuxi started to fiddle with the world:
The result people did comply, but they were not united.
The natural potential of things declined further:
as when Shennong and the Yellow Emperor started to fiddle with the world:
then as a result the people kept the peace but did not comply.
The natural potential of things declined further:
as when Yao and Shun started fiddling with the world,
they made up some fashions of governing and transmogrifying things
thus fouling up the purity and the pristine simplicity there was:
through their "excellence" they distanced themselves from the Way,
through their regulated behaviour they endangered their natural potential,
and it was only after this that they got rid of their basic nature so as to follow their (misguided) mind (full of prejudiced subjectivities).
One mind understood the other mind all too well
and only as they turned out not to be in a position to impose fixed order on the world
did they bring in this element of "higher aesthetics",
and they augmented this with the element of "broad appeal".
The higher aesthetics annihilated what had been of substance,
the "broad appeal" drowned what had been honest attitudes:
and it was only at this stage that the people came to be thoroughly confused,
unable to revert to their basic nature and instincts so as to get back to their original state.
Hence it appears
that the world has lost its Way,
and that the Way has lost (it grip on) the world.
The world and the Way have lost touch with eachother,
so how could men imbued with the Way emerge and thrive in this world,
and how could this world come to thrive on the Way?
When the Way has no means of thriving in this world,
and when the world has no means of thriving on the Way,
then even if a sage does not, in fact, stay in his mountain forests
his natural potential will remain hidden.
Being hidden
he need not hide himself.
The recluse gentlemen of ancient times
by no means hid away their persons
and refused to show off their persons.
they by no means closed off their proposals,
and failed to put forward any;
they by no means hid their wisdom
and did not set it to work:
The thing was that the destiny defined for them by the times was not at all right for them.
When they fitted into the destiny defined for them by the times and they fully got their way throughout this world,
then they reverted to the One and left no trace;
and when they did not fit into the destiny defined for them by the times
and they became a complete flop in the world
then they sank their roos deep and found their peace in the Absolute and waited for things to come:
this was the Way (of the ancients) of preserving their person
The Way of the ancients of preserving their person
was not by embellishing their wisdom through argument,
it was not to embrace the whole world through their wisdom,
it was not to embrace the whole of their natural potential through wisdom:
precariously they held their place
and they reverted to their basic nature,
己what more did their own Selves effect in this world?
The Way one certainly does not implement in any petty manner,
one's natural potential one certainly is not familiar with in any petty manner.
petty awareness harms one's natual potential,
petty implementation harms one's Way.
Therefore it is said:
It is all about getting one's Self right, that is all.
That wherein one's delight is unbounded is called the realisation of one's aspirations.
What the ancients called "realising one's aspirations"
was not a matter of carriages and official headgear.
it just means that there was nothing that would add to the joy, that is all.
What one means by "realising one's aspirations"
refers to carriages and official caps.
The carriages belong to the person
but they are not part of his basic nature or his destiny.
(Such) things turn up out of the blue, and they stay for a limited time.
One occupies them for a limited time:
the turning up of these things one cannot be blocked,
their slipping away cannot be stopped.
That is why one does not become overbearing because of any carriages or official hats,
and he does not rush into vulgarity because of failure or penury:
his delight with one or the other is one and the same,
and that he is simply without worries.
Nowadays, on the other hand, when a temporary thing slips away people are unhappy about it.
From this perspective
even if people are delighted with something
they are never other than wildly confused.
Therefore it is said:
Those who lose their own selves to mere things,
who forfeit their basic nature to sheer vulgarity
these are called people who have got it all wrong.
When the seaon of the autumn floods has come,
all streams pour into the Yellow river,
and as the flood rises to such heights
that from the shores of the rivers and the islets
that (for the high waves) one could not make out clearly the oxen and the horses on the other side.
It is at this point that the Lord of the Yellow River happily pleased with himself
and he fancies that all that is beautiful in the world converges on himself.
Following the stream he travels east
to reach the Northern Sea:
there he faces further eastward and looks out,
but he sees to end to the waters.
And at that point the Lord of the Yellow River turns his face round
gazing into the distance over the Ocean he addresses Spirit Ruo with a sigh:
"There is a popular proverb
Having learnt about all manner of doctrines
one thinks oneself wiser than everyone else:
I am a case in point.
For I have heard people thinking little of what they had heard from Confucius,
and despised Bo Yi's notions of duty,
and from the start I refused to believe them.
Now I have witnessed your inexhaustible infinitude
if I do not turn up at your gate to study with you
that will be dangerous:
I would become the laughing stock of of all those who know what they are doing."
Ruo of the North Sea said:
"With a frog in a well one cannot chat about the Sea:
he is limited by his dilapidated place;
with a summer insect you cannot chat about ice:
it is adapted to its season.
with a parochial gentleman one cannot chat about the Way:
he is tied down by indoctrination.
Now you have emerged from your shores
you are surveying the great Sea
and at that point you understand your own deficiencies:
You are the sort one will be able to discuss the great principles with.
Of all the waters in the world
none are greater than those of sea:
myriads of streams converge on it
and one has no idea when this will ever stop, but the sea does not fill up.
At Weilü water oozes out from the sea,
and one has no idea when this will ever stop, but the sea never gets empty.
In spring and in autumn the sea is remains unchanged
floods and droughts the sea knows nothing of:
this is because the sea goes far beyond the flow of Yangzi and the Yellow River,
immeasurable it is, and innumerable.
But I would never for this reason be self-important.
I just line up my body with Heaven and Earth
and receive my vital force from Yin and Yang:
I'm between the sky and the earth
like a little pebble, a little shrub on a big mountain,
for the moment I subsist here, and I see (vividly) how little I count!
how should I go on to be self-important?
You calculate what the Four Seas are between the sky and the earth!
Aren't these Four Seas like slits in a pellet?
You calculate what our central states are within the seas!
Aren't our Central States like a tiny grain of rice in the Great Granary (of the universe)?
When we verbalise the (infinite) number of creatures (in this world)
we call them "myriad"
and man constitutes only one of these (kinds).
Men gather all over the Nine Regions of the world
wherever grain and edibles grow
wherever boats and vehicles can reach,
but man is only one of the creatures that live there:
this one must be held up against the myriad kinds of creatures in the world:
aren't (we) men like some tiny hair on the body of a horse?
What the Five Emperors held in succession
what the Three Kings competed for,
what benevolent men worried about,
what hired men work hard on
is no more than this (infinitesimal part of the universe).
Bo Yi resigned from it for the sake of a name,
Confucius talked about it to show off his broad culture:
These were cases of being full of oneself!
Aren't they like you just a moment ago being full of yourself regarding those floods of yours.
The Lord of the Yellow River said:
"This is all very well, but when I consider Heaven and Earth bigger
than a small hair,
I do have a point, don't I?"
Ruo of the Northern Sea said: "No, you don't!
When you assess the things of this world, they are inexhaustible:
times never stop,
divisions are never constant,
cyclical change is not stable (=固).
Thus great understanding surveys across the distant and the close,
and will thus never hold small things to be (necessarily) of little account,
nor will be take big things to be (necessarily) of great importance.
He knows that the measure of things is inexhaustible.
He critically examines past and present
and as a result is not upset about things that are far off,
and has no eager hopes (even) for things within his grasp.
He understands that times are achanging,
and he investigates what is substantial and what is not.
As a result he does not exult over success
nor does he worry over failure:
he understands the inconstancy of one's lot,
he is clear about the plain way of natural processes.
And so he is not particularly pleased with being alive,
nor does he regard death as a disaster:
he understands that cosmic developments cannot be ascribed to definite reasons.
When one calculates what men understand
it is nowhere near what they do not understand.
The time they have lived
is nowhere near the time the time they were not yet born:
one is seeking to understand exhaustively that which is extremely large with means that are extremely small
and so one gets completely lost and cannot achieve one's aspirations.
Looking at things from this perspective:
How, in addition, could one ever be sure that a flimsy hair is a sufficient basis on which to fix the measure of the infinitesimally small,
how could one ever be sure that (our universe of) Heaven and Earth are sufficient basis on which to exhausively explain the vast realm of infinitude?"
The Lord of the Yellow River said:
"The public debaters of our world all maintain
'the ininitesimally fine has no shape,
and the infinitely large has no circumference'
is that the true situation?
Ruo of the Northern Sea said:
"If you look at what is large from the point of view of the small, you will not get to the bottom of it;
if you look at the small from the point of view of the large, you will not get a clear view of it.
The subtle is the most fine kind of the small;
the gigantic is the most enormous kind of the large:
So keeping them apart is by convenience:
these distinctions are made according to circumstances.
Now as for what is quintessential or coarse
these categories are agreed upon in relation to physical shape
and what has no shape
cannot be cut up numerically into parts;
what cannot be circumscribed
cannot be numerically exhausted.
What can be discursively accounted for is the coarse or massive aspects of things;
what one can reach through thought are the subtler aspects of things;
what words are incapable of accountig for
and what thought is incapable to reach through inquiry
is not defined for fineness or.coarsenss.
Therefore?? the conduct of the great man
does not result in harming others
and it is not a matter benevolent generosity;
his initiatives are not for his own profit
and he does not even look down upon the minion at the gate of his home;
he refuses to compete for wealth of any sort,

his activities consist in following the ways of the mob

The ranks and stipends of this (vulgar) world are not suffcient to encourage him
death penalties and public shame are not sufficient to make him feel humiliated:
he understands that right and wrong are indistinguishable

I have heard it said:
"The man possessed of the Way will never be heard of,
the consummation of natural potential is not a matter of success,
the great man has no Self.
This is the ultimate point of an allotted fate (that one can hope to reach).'
The Lord of the Yellow River said:
"Either from an (objective) angle external to things, or from a (subjective) angle internal to things,
how can one get to precisely assess or measure its relative status? How can one get to measure its extension?"
Ruo of the Northern Sea said:
"From the (objective) point of view of the Way
there is no nobility or baseness of things;
from the (subjective) points of view of the things (themselves),
these (tend to) find themselves noble, and they find each other base;
from the (sociological) point of view of prevailing custom
nobility or baseness is not in people themselves.
From the point of view of relative size
when on the basis of something being larger than something else we consider that thing as large,

and if on the basis of being smaller than something else we consider that thing to be small
then nothing in the world will fail to be small.
When one properly understands that (our 'universe of') Heaven and Earth is effectively (something like) a tiny grain of rice
and when one understands that a downy hair is effectively (something like) a mountain,
then the mathematics of relative size has come into view.
from the point of view of useful function,
when on the basis of having whatever merit they have one considers them to have merit

and when on the basis of lacking whatever merit they lack one considers them to have no merit

And if one understands that East and West are the opposites of each other but cannot be without each other
then the distribution of merit is determined. [Merit is always complementary.??]
From the point of view of subjectivity
when on the basis of whatever one finds so-and-so one considers that to be (actually) so-and-so

and if one the basis of whatever one considers not to be so-and-so one takes them actually not to be so-and-so,

Once one has understood how Yao and Jie each consider themselves right and consider each other wrong,

In ancient times Shun succeeded Yao when the latter abdicated,

Tang and Wu struggled and became kinds,
Duke Bai struggled and was destroyed.
From this it appears
that the ritual practice competitive struggle and of ritual abdication
and the conduct of Yao and Jie
count as noble or base at given times only

With a big beam you can ram a city wall

that is to say one makes different use of tools.
Thoroughbreds like Qiji and Hualiu

that is to say they differ with regard to their skills.
that is to say it differs with regard to its inborn capacities.
The owl catches fleas at night
and distinguishes a minute hair
but in the daytime it may open its fierce eyes wide
and still fails to see a mound or a mountain (right before it):
Therefore it is said:
So apparently one faithfully agrees with what (one considers) is right and disrgards what (one considers) is wrong,

But such an attitude is not to understand the prinicples of Heaven and Earth,

this is like faithfully conforming to Heaven and disregarding Earth,

it is clear that these methods canot be successfully implemented.

Emperors and kings differ in their practice of abdicating,

those who keep in accordance with their times

Be quiet, Lord of the Yellow River.
How could you ever understand the first thing about nobility and baseness
about the unimportant and the important?"
The Lord of the Yellow River said: Well, in that case, what am I to do
and what am I to avoid doing?
And as for my refusing or accepting, opting for and rejecting
how, in the end, am I to handle this?"
Ruo of the Northern Sea said:
"From the perspective of the Way

These are just endless categorial regurgitations.
Never inhibit your aspirations,

What counts as many, what as few?

Quite stern you have to be, as when a state has a ruler
